title: Does the smartwatch make phone users more vulnerable to hacking? - Quora

response.answer_text: there have been a few blue-tooth exploits in the past. Blue-tooth is definitely a vulnerability if you don’t use it properly. Make sure you reduce it’s usage as much as possible and avoid having your device visible all the time. From my understanding most smart-watches and other blue-tooth devices have an authentication feature. Make good use of this feature. Also I’m pretty sure most data sent over blue-tooth is encrypted. I also imagine security and encryption improve with the latest blue-tooth technologies. The latest now is Blue-tooth 5.0 so having the latest decreases risk.

It could. They’re bluetooth devices that have somewhat privileged access to the phone they’re paired with. It’s another entry point to potentially compromise the phone if that’s an attacker’s goal. Not having a smart watch is more secure than having one. However, in the grand scheme of things it is a negligible concern. I’ve had my LG Urbane smartwatch for a long time now. It hasn’t resulted in a compromise of my phone yet (as far as I know anyway).
